list_definition.definition: to come, or bring, back to consciousness, strength, health etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: They attempted to revive the woman who had fainted
His hopes of seeing her again were revived.

list_definition.definition: to come or bring back to use etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: This old custom has recently (been) revived.

list_ex_of_english: The rent dinners continued, but the harvest suppers that he had revived in 1909 appear to have been a casualty of this period.
Evidently, the events across the border were reviving dormant resentments throughout the western frontier lands.
Interest in the buildings revived in the 1960s.
It is much more feasible for a community to revive the symbolic functions of a language, without necessarily changing their language of communicative function.
In order to revive private renting, rents were deregulated on new tenancies.
The low success we had in reviving cryopreserved embryos certainly implies that the process could have been stressful to the survivors.
Animals were revived under a heat lamp and returned to home cages.
To achieve this end, they sometimes resorted to reviving bygone tribal identities or inventing new ones altogether.
